cab.content: SE C RE T.No* 0.A.B./175. General Headquarters,British Armies in Prance.16th April. 1918.Sir,I have the honour to forward herewith a report received from the G.O.C., Royal Air Force, on the bombing raid carried out by the Ochey Squadrons on the 12th instant,I have the honour to be, Sir,Your obedient Servant,(Sd.) K. digram,Brig.-General, for Field Marshal, Commanding-in-Chief, British Armies in France.The Secretary, War Office, London, S.V.r. DETAILED REPORT ON BOMB RAID CARRIED OUT12TH APRIL, 1918.12 De Havilland 4*s left at 9.50 a.m. to bomb therailway sidings, and station at METZ-SABLOh. One machine was forced to return with engine trouble. The remainder reached their objective and dropped 22 112-lb. bombs from 14,000 feet. Good bursts were-observed on the railway sidings, buildings alongside the railway triangle and in the triangle itself. Three bursts were seen in the sheds on the goods sidings and one on the railway at the goods sidings. 15 photographs were taken which shew excellent shooting on to the line.Only one enemy aircraft was seen, which, however, was 3,000 feet below the formation.Anti-aircraft fire was moderate.The weather was cloudy, wind W.S.W. 16 m.p.h* at 10,000 feet, visibility good.All machines returned safely at 12.50 p.m.(Sd.) C.L.iJ.hEh.*"XL,In the Field,13th April, 1918.Brigadier-General, G.O.C., 8th. Brigade, Royal Air Force.
